hypeR

Anthony Federico

Boston University School of Medicine, Boston, MA

Stefano Monti

Boston University School of Medicine, Boston, MA

April 30, 2019

Source: vignettes/hypeR.Rmd
hypeR.Rmd

Introduction

Geneset enrichment is an important step in many biological data analysis workflows, particularly in bioinformatics and computational biology. At a basic level, one is testing if a group of genes is overrepresented in a series of pre-defined sets of genes, which typically signify some biological relevance. The R package hypeR enables users to easily perform this type of analysis via a hypergeometric test with a focus on easing downstream visualization, analysis, and reporting. Additionally, users can use custom genesets that are easily defined, extending the analysis of genes to other areas of interest such as proteins, microbes, metabolites etc. The hypeR package is designed to make routine geneset enrichment seamless for scientist working in R.

Installation

Download the package from Bioconductor.

if (!requireNamespace("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE))
install.packages("BiocManager")
BiocManager::install("hypeR")

Or install the development version of the package from Bioconductor.

BiocManager::install("montilab/hypeR")

If not using the current version of R, try installing from our dev branch.

devtools::install_github("montilab/hypeR", ref="dev")

Load the package into an R session.

library(hypeR)

Basics

Example Data

Example of a signature

Here we define our signature of interest as a group of genes randomly sampled from the estrogen-dependent gene expression gset. A signature is simply a vector of symbols.

signatures <- readRDS(system.file("extdata/signatures.rds", package="hypeR"))
signature <- signatures$signature
head(signature)
## [1] "GTF2F1"    "HIST1H2AJ" "KANK1"     "STAG1"     "FKBP4"     "SMC1A"

Example of a geneset

Here we use a genesets example from REACTOME. A geneset is simply a list of vectors, therefore, one can use any custom geneset in their analysis, as long as it is appropriately defined.

gsets <- readRDS(system.file("extdata/gsets.rds", package="hypeR"))
gsets <- gsets$REACTOME
head(names(gsets))
## [1] "REACTOME_3_UTR_MEDIATED_TRANSLATIONAL_REGULATION"                        
## [2] "REACTOME_A_TETRASACCHARIDE_LINKER_SEQUENCE_IS_REQUIRED_FOR_GAG_SYNTHESIS"
## [3] "REACTOME_ABACAVIR_TRANSPORT_AND_METABOLISM"                              
## [4] "REACTOME_ABC_FAMILY_PROTEINS_MEDIATED_TRANSPORT"                         
## [5] "REACTOME_ABCA_TRANSPORTERS_IN_LIPID_HOMEOSTASIS"                         
## [6] "REACTOME_ABORTIVE_ELONGATION_OF_HIV1_TRANSCRIPT_IN_THE_ABSENCE_OF_TAT"
head(gsets[[1]])
## [1] "EIF1AX" "EIF2S1" "EIF2S2" "EIF2S3" "EIF3A"  "EIF3B"

Hyper enrichment

All workflows begin with performing hyper enrichment with hypeR. Often we are just interested in a single signature, as described above. In this case, hypeR will return a hyp object. This object contains relevant information to the enrichment results and is recognized by downstream methods.

hyp_obj <- hypeR(signature, gsets, fdr=0.05)
print(hyp_obj)
## hyp object: 
##   data: 73 x 8
##   args: symbols
##         gsets
##         gsets_relational
##         bg
##         min_drawsize
##         pval_cutoff
##         fdr_cutoff
##         verbose
hyp_df <- hyp_obj$as.data.frame()
print(hyp_df[5:10,1:4])
##                                        pval     fdr set.annotated set.size
## REACTOME_RNA_POL_I_TRANSCRIPTION    1.9e-33 2.6e-31            22      100
## REACTOME_RNA_POL_I_PROMOTER_OPENING 4.1e-33 4.6e-31            20      100
## REACTOME_CHROMOSOME_MAINTENANCE     8.8e-32 8.5e-30            23      100
## REACTOME_PACKAGING_OF_TELOMERE_ENDS 2.8e-31 2.4e-29            18      100
## REACTOME_AMYLOIDS                   3.4e-30 2.6e-28            20      100
## REACTOME_MEIOTIC_RECOMBINATION      7.6e-30 5.1e-28            20      100

Show an interactive table

hyp_show(hyp_obj, simple=FALSE, stylish=TRUE)

Set background population size

Because genomic experiments often vary in the number of genes probed, it is important to be able to adjust the background population size accordingly to ensure accurate enrichment statistics.

hyp_obj <- hypeR(signature, gsets, bg=10000, fdr=0.05)

Save results to excel

hyp_to_excel(hyp_obj, file_path="pathways.xlsx")

Save results to table

hyp_to_table(hyp_obj, file_path="pathways.txt")

Visualizations

Plot results

One can visualize the top enriched pathways using hyp_plot which will return a horizontal bar plot. Each bar is a geneset, where dark blue represents the proportion of signature genes found in the entire geneset.

hyp_plot(hyp_obj, return_plots=TRUE)

Enrichment map

One can visualize the top enriched pathways using hyp_emap which will return an enrichment map. Each node represents a geneset, where the shade of red indicates the normalized significance of enrichment. Hover over the node to view the raw value. Edges represent geneset similarity, calculated by either jaccard or overlap similarity metrics.

hyp_emap(hyp_obj, similarity_cutoff=0.5, return_plots=TRUE)

Advanced

Relational genesets

When dealing with hundreds of genesets, itâ€™s often useful to understand the relationships between them. This allows researchers to summarize many enriched pathways as more general biological processes. To do this, we rely on curated relationships defined between them. For example, REACTOME conveniently defines their genesets in a hiearchy of pathways. This data can be formatted into a relational genesets object called rgsets.

rgsets_lst <- readRDS(system.file("extdata/rgsets.rds", package="hypeR"))
rgsets_obj <- rgsets_lst$REACTOME

Relational genesets have three data atrributes including gsets, nodes, and edges. Using hierarchical terms, the gsets attribute includes the geneset information for the leaf nodes of the hiearchy, the nodes attribute describes all nodes in the hiearchical, including internal nodes, and the edges attribute describes the edges in the hiearchy.

$gsets

gsets <- rgsets_obj$gsets
names(gsets)[800:805]
## [1] "MET activates PTK2 signaling"    "MET activates PTPN11"           
## [3] "MET activates RAP1 and RAC1"     "MET activates RAS signaling"    
## [5] "MET activates STAT3"             "MET interacts with TNS proteins"

$nodes

nodes <- rgsets_obj$nodes
nodes[1123:1128,]
##                                         label            id length
## R-HSA-8874081    MET activates PTK2 signaling R-HSA-8874081     18
## R-HSA-8865999            MET activates PTPN11 R-HSA-8865999      5
## R-HSA-8875555     MET activates RAP1 and RAC1 R-HSA-8875555     11
## R-HSA-8851805     MET activates RAS signaling R-HSA-8851805     11
## R-HSA-8875791             MET activates STAT3 R-HSA-8875791      3
## R-HSA-8875513 MET interacts with TNS proteins R-HSA-8875513      5

$edges

edges <- rgsets_obj$edges
edges[1994:1999,]
##               from            to
## 1994 R-HSA-8875878 R-HSA-8874081
## 1995 R-HSA-8875878 R-HSA-8875513
## 1996 R-HSA-8875878 R-HSA-8875555
## 1997 R-HSA-8876384 R-HSA-8875360
## 1998 R-HSA-8876384 R-HSA-8876493
## 1999 R-HSA-8878159 R-HSA-8941855

All workflows begin with performing hyper enrichment with hypeR. Note that when passing an rgsets object, ensure gsets_relational=TRUE. Otherwise, hypeR will treat it as a list of unstructured gsets.

hyp_obj <- hypeR(signature, rgsets_obj, gsets_relational=TRUE, bg=7842, fdr=0.05)

Hierarchy map

One can visualize the top enriched pathways using hyp_hmap which will return a hiearchy map. Each node represents a geneset, where the shade of the gold border indicates the normalized significance of enrichment. Hover over the leaf nodes to view the raw value. Double click internal nodes to cluster their first degree connections.s Edges represent a directed relationship between genesets in the hiearchy.

hyp_hmap(hyp_obj, top=60, return_plots=TRUE)

Multiple signatures

Other times we are looking at multiple signatures that may have been defined in a single experiment. In this case, we can feed hypeR a named list of signatures and a multihyp object will be returned. This object is essentially just multiple hyp objects. However it is recognized and handled differently by downstream visualization and analysis tools.

signatures <- readRDS(system.file("extdata/signatures.rds", package="hypeR"))
experiment <- signatures$experiment
names(experiment)
## [1] "YAP-KO Signature"      "YAP-KO Up-regulated"   "YAP-KO Down-regulated"
head(experiment[[1]])
## [1] "CD55"     "IGLC1"    "IGKV1-5"  "C9"       "IGLV4-60" "IGLV4-3"
multihyp_obj <- hypeR(experiment, gsets, bg=35423)
print(multihyp_obj)
## multihyp object: 
## YAP-KO Signature 
## hyp object: 
##   data: 1552 x 8
##   args: symbols
##         gsets
##         gsets_relational
##         bg
##         min_drawsize
##         pval_cutoff
##         fdr_cutoff
##         verbosemultihyp object: 
## YAP-KO Up-regulated 
## hyp object: 
##   data: 1552 x 8
##   args: symbols
##         gsets
##         gsets_relational
##         bg
##         min_drawsize
##         pval_cutoff
##         fdr_cutoff
##         verbosemultihyp object: 
## YAP-KO Down-regulated 
## hyp object: 
##   data: 1552 x 8
##   args: symbols
##         gsets
##         gsets_relational
##         bg
##         min_drawsize
##         pval_cutoff
##         fdr_cutoff
##         verbose

Save results to excel

When saving a multihyp object to excel, each signature is exported to its own tab.

hyp_to_excel(multihyp_obj, file_path="pathways.xlsx")

Save results to table

When saving a multihyp object to a table, each signature is exported as its own table in a single directory.

hyp_to_table(multihyp_obj, file_path="pathways.txt")

When plotting a multihyp object, each signatures is plotted and returned separately.

Plot results

p <- hyp_plot(multihyp_obj, return_plots=TRUE)
names(p)
## [1] "YAP-KO Signature"      "YAP-KO Up-regulated"   "YAP-KO Down-regulated"
p[[1]]

Enrichment map

p <- hyp_emap(multihyp_obj, top=100, similarity_cutoff=0.2, val="pval", multihyp_titles=FALSE, return_plots=TRUE)
names(p)
## [1] "YAP-KO Signature"      "YAP-KO Up-regulated"   "YAP-KO Down-regulated"
p[[1]]

Multiple experiments

Sometimes, we are generating reports for mutliple signatures across multiple experiments. Typically, the best way to manage this data is to process it all at once and generate a markdown report to analyze ourselves or share with our collaborators.

signatures <- readRDS(system.file("extdata/signatures.rds", package="hypeR"))
project <- signatures$project
names(project)
## [1] "YAP-KO Experiment" "TNF-KO Experiment" "TAZ-KO Experiment"
names(project[[1]])
## [1] "YAP-KO Signature"      "YAP-KO Up-regulated"   "YAP-KO Down-regulated"
head(project[[1]][[1]])
## [1] "ELOC"   "TRIM71" "KLHL13" "HECTD3" "PSMD6"  "WSB1"
lmultihyp_obj <- lapply(project, function(x) hypeR(x, gsets, bg=35423))
names(lmultihyp_obj)
## [1] "YAP-KO Experiment" "TNF-KO Experiment" "TAZ-KO Experiment"
print(lmultihyp_obj[[1]])
## multihyp object: 
## YAP-KO Signature 
## hyp object: 
##   data: 1552 x 8
##   args: symbols
##         gsets
##         gsets_relational
##         bg
##         min_drawsize
##         pval_cutoff
##         fdr_cutoff
##         verbosemultihyp object: 
## YAP-KO Up-regulated 
## hyp object: 
##   data: 1552 x 8
##   args: symbols
##         gsets
##         gsets_relational
##         bg
##         min_drawsize
##         pval_cutoff
##         fdr_cutoff
##         verbosemultihyp object: 
## YAP-KO Down-regulated 
## hyp object: 
##   data: 1552 x 8
##   args: symbols
##         gsets
##         gsets_relational
##         bg
##         min_drawsize
##         pval_cutoff
##         fdr_cutoff
##         verbose

Markdown reports

hyp_to_rmd will accept multiple formats, including a single hyp or multihyp objects as well as a list of either, including a list of hyp or multihyp objects together. When a list of multihyp objects are passed for example, each experiment will become its own section, while each signature becomes its own tab within that section. Lists of keyword arguments can be passed for hyp_plot, hyp_emap, and hyp_hmap, allowing customization of their functionality per report.

hyp_to_rmd(lmultihyp_obj,
           file_path="hyper-enrichment.rmd",
           title="Hyper Enrichment (hypeR)",
           subtitle="YAP, TNF, and TAZ Knockout Experiments",
           author="Anthony Federico, Stefano Monti",
           show_plots=T,
           show_emaps=T,
           show_hmaps=T,
           show_tables=T)
